replies.author: @smokypies
replies.text: I am a white/white passing, English-only speaking, Hispanic woman living in a west coast blue state in community with many white men. These people are tired of the two old guys, and many Obama-Trump-Biden voters think Trump is a worse candidate than Hillary was in 2016.  Even working class men who always vote (R) are planning to stay home. I am fully expecting and prepared to be disappointed by the larger American electorate or the court system, but Trump is a uniquely bad candidate with incredible weaknesses.

text: I walked out of my apartment building in Harlem today and directly into a ‚ÄòBlack Women for Harris‚Äô rally at the Harriet Tubman statue and when I walked by again like 20 mins later Cordell Cleare was addressing a crowd 3-4x the size of when I originally passed that essentially stopped traffic on St Nicholas and 122nd. It was awesome.

author: @RNNNPTH
text:
I'm a leftist (also an Indian American who supposedly could be swayed by Kamala Harris' part Indian identity-- for the record there are too many bad humans in the Indian diaspora for that to do anything for me), not a fan of Harris or any Democrats, but definitely recognize how catastrophic Trump winning could be. I also haven't been swayed by the supposed virtue or benefit of voting symbolically or for third parties in a long time (I did vote for Nader in 2000). I was probably not going to be able to stomach voting again for Biden (I did in 2020 and not proud of it). Despite Harris being a part of that administration, Biden being replaced has really cleared most of the ill stench the prospect of voting for for the Democratic ticket, and I'm not under any delusion that Harris will be all that different. But the buck stops with Biden, and with Harris at the top of the ticket, the buck still stops with Biden (at least until/if she becomes president). At any rate voting for "the lesser of two evils" rhetoric should be retired in favor of "pick the administration we can resist better". Liberals will be complacent if Democrats win but they were never the allies you want anyway. We should normalize the idea that even if you vote for someone you still have a responsibility to resist and pressure against their oppressive policies, which Harris will likely have if she wins.

With regards to the white woman question, I doubt many white woman who voted for Trump in 2016 and 2020 are going to be swayed to vote differently especially with a Black woman at the top of the ticket, but morbidly, I wonder if a statistically significant number of older white people have died off (the pandemic killed and is still killing a lot of people) and will be replaced by younger voters who turned 18.

replies.text: I do believe abortion rights is a reason some white woman vote for Harris

replies.author: @JDBaldBabyVance
replies.text: Morbid is right, but you do have a point. Trump did NOT do his voter base any favors with his handling of covid. Granted, that affected us and our loved ones too and even now it's na√Øve to suggest we're "past" it, but we're the ones still here who tried to protect ourselves and others. Bet Trump lost a lot of would be racist voters with the antivax crap.

replies.author: @samwight
replies.text: I generally agree but I don't think either administration is going to be great to organize under. Stop Cop City protesters were literally executed by police. University students protesting peacefully were beaten to shit, arrested, and had the full arm of the state weapons against them. Both of those happened under a Dem administration.

author: @amoss9737
text: My only issue is feeling like I can never vote for what I want. We‚Äôre constantly in this cycle of voting for someone in order to block ‚Äúevil‚Äù. When do we get to vote for our actual interests without the constant fear of rights being taken away?

replies.author: @user-lp2nz7vq6b
replies.text: Right now. This election is when you can vote for your interest, will be one of the most progressive, forward-thinking people to ever win the White House.

replies.author: @TreeHairedGingerAle
replies.text:
It's understandable.

My thinking: vote. Or don't vote. But _organize._ Both before and after. People need to stop going back to sleep. 

Stopgaps are fine, but what matters the most rn is community and network building...because the US government will NEVER take care of the People the way that _The People_ can take care of the People.

replies.author: @Beastw1ck
replies.text: @amoss9737 Probably once we get rid of Trump. Obama McCain and Obama Romney were two elections where neither candidate was a dangerous extremist.

replies.author: @thzene4967
replies.text: Honestly when the right shifts to policy alternatives other than ones that ban and limits. As long as that's their game it's the thing we'll always be fighting.

replies.author: @amoss9737

replies.author: @amoss9737
replies.text: @thzene4967 this is exactly my point. It‚Äôs very exhausting, especially for us in red states, to constantly have to fight off people who only want to infiltrate and conquer. This leaves you not really making a choice but just voting to block other people‚Äôs destructive choices.

replies.author: @jojodelacroix
replies.text: Voting isn't about expressing your conscious frankly. It's tactical.

replies.author: @hrwise89
replies.text:
‚Äã@amoss9737 my guess is that it will be a long-ass time before we will truly be voting for a *president* in a way that isn't just blocking something worse.

In terms of how we get there, I've heard some pretty good arguments that we need to do away with first past the post voting and move to ranked choice so we can actually vote for third parties without throwing away votes each time critical mass isn't reached. Alternately, if we could get said third parties to focus on local elections / congress seats, that might be a start too.

If we can push the shit out of those two things, maybe, some day, far in the future, we could vote for a president without plugging our noses?

replies.author: @WeAreNotGoingBackEver
replies.text: I don't ever recall feeling this pressure.

author: @towandacastaneira8491
text: She‚Äôs also going to need a House and Senate majority to get any policy positions she wants to implement. She definitely can‚Äôt do it alone.

replies.author: @tylergriffin3667
replies.text: Tbf, I think the tactic here isn't as much about getting thing passed as it is about preventing things from being passed. AKA Project 2025. Yes, it's a delay tactic. Yes I hate it with every fiber of me soul. But if we're gonna be honest and work with the real material conditions we have, it makes sense. I can't bring myself to be enthusiastic or hopefull; living where I do it wouldn't help her cause much for me to advocate and campaign for her, which I'm not sure I could stomache, but I'm gonna vote for her.

author: @RNNNPTH
text:
Okay, I just went down a rabbit hole with the whole 'Coconut" meme... a lot of memes and internet culture goes over my head. At any rate, I've learned the origins are Kamala Harris quoting her South Indian mother, so it has decidedly South Indian origins. Her mother is from Tamil Nadu (my family is from Kerala, the South Indian state that borders Tamil Nadu). Coconuts are very culturally significant in Kerala, even more so than Tamil Nadu (example, in Tamil Nadu they sell young (green) coconuts on the street with straws for drinking coconut water out of them, but you never see that in Kerala because it's important to let coconuts fully ripen there). I do find it a bit weird that there's a lot of discourse around this meme that is completely divorced from the obviously South Indian origins.

Also, among the South Asian diaspora,  South Asian people with white assimilation aspirations are derisively referred to as 'coconuts' (brown on the outside, white on the inside). All things told I'd say white Harris supporters should ditch the 'coconut' meme.

replies.author: @ChristopherSadlowski
replies.text:
I feel you. I'm ANGRY that the establishment Democrats forced Biden on us by not holding a primary. I'm ANGRY that Biden was so deluded that he thought he was the ONLY person in this entire country who could beat Trump. I'm ANGRY that Biden assumed his eighty year old ass could last another FOUR YEARS in office. I'm ANGRY at Biden for wasting our goddamn time. I'm. ANGRY. 
But...Kamala isn't a terrible choice now. I'm at least comfortable voting for her instead of the begrudging dread I had voting for Biden. It's really annoying me how Boomers simply refuse to let go of power. It's annoying that they won't retire, don't trust us, their children, to take over, and appear to believe they're going to live forever to continue forcing their garbage that doesn't work anymore on us. It's annoying that it's taking DEATH to force open the seats of power instead of retirement. I'm bitter...but I'm not giving up just yet.

author: @ktsig287
text:
The American electorate is so strange sometimes.

My 76 year old step-grandma voted for Trump and was planning to vote for him again.

The other day, she was "well i am just tickled and amazed that we will see the first woman president in my lifetime. How exciting! I can't wait to cast my vote for Kamala Harris."

It's like...huh...what? How did you go from Trump to Kamala? I won't argue it, but I swear so many people just get vibes and change their minds.

She called Hilary Clinton "nasty and corrupt", but now she's like "I don't like the way they're talking about Kamala Harris..that is just lowly and uncalled for." 

I know so many people who hated hilary who are now all in for Harris.

replies.author: @ktsig287

author: @spontaneousmixx
text:
I wish I had been part of this conversation. So much  Identity based focused right out the gate.  People liked Harris in the 2020 primary UNTIL she waffled on her policy positions.  Go back and look at her polling numbers and compare that with the dates when she had reneged on her support for Medicare for all.  This was her turning point.  It ain't about her identity it's about her consistency. 

If there's any MAIN criticism i have of her, it's that she shifted ideals for her own political advancement, not as bad as Tulsi did, but because of this, i don't know if her initial policy positions when she was more progressive are her true positions, or if she was like, "let me try the Bernie approach, oh he's got that locked up, let me try a more corporate angle." Or if it was donors that got to her. That shift in the primary i can never forget.

author: @jeremiahp9225
text: Olay here's my take on everything, (Sorry about it being long) I love you, Garrison & Rebecca!! ‚ù§‚ù§ First I really think you should invite @2rawtooreal on your show. He's a very intelligent dude & I think he'd bring a great aspect to the discussion. Ok so, I understand the statistical aspect of that on paper, in black & white & based on America being deep rooted in Racism, sexism & misogyny that "she can't win" but we must not be statistically stagnant meaning we need to understand that without hope there can be no systematic change so we must be hopeful & have optimism about Kamala Harris having a chance of winning because we as a society get so focused on the reality, facts & data that we're scared to dream or scared to be optimistic & as human beings, I think that's a problem. Everything from the ending of slavery, to the moon landing, to electing the first black president all started with hope & optimism. The chance of her winning might not be great but there's a chance nonetheless. Also the reason why people go straight to her record as a prosecutor & AG for a reason to not vote for her is because they tend to not have an intellectual factual reason as to why they wouldn't vote for her. They'll just say what everybody said & become a bandwagon person.  People like that are usually ignorant, they're mis-educated,  misinformed, mislead especially when it comes to politics. We live in an Idiocracy meaning people tend to believe something that's word of mouth rather than doing their own research. We must put an end to that & encourage & even demand that people study on these important issues & learn the real qualifications of people before they open their mouth. They need to read articles & books about it. To Rebecca's point, I think she has been pointing out her agenda this entire week. A lot of Democrats who have rallied behind her have also laid out her agenda. To Garrison's take on VP Kamala doing Dances & stuff on TikTok & black sororities. Garrison you're wrong. I'm a proud Gen Z member & I actually didn't download TikTok until last week believe it or not & I said I would never download it. She has energized me about politics that much. Since I've been on there, I've seen hundreds of thousands of people like hundreds of videos of members of Black Sorority groups supporting her, Charlie XCX fans supporting, Beyonce fans & alot of Democrats in General. So I would have to disagree, I think that it's connecting to a lot of people that are supporting & donating to her, more than y'all might think. She's moving with the time & era in which we all live.  It's like y'all just want "Facts, policies & nothing else" from her which doesn't make any sense, even Obama had humor. Do you want her to act like a politician from the 1950s? No, it's called being relatable, being fun, having a sense of humor, realizing she's a human just like us,  ENERGIZING THE DEMOCRATIC PARTY!!! It doesn't mean when it's time to be serious, she can't be serious. Just some food for thought. By the way I'm a progressive Democrat saying this stuff!! Another thing, I love Project Coconut & it's becoming a movement. üá∫üá≤üíöü••üå¥

author: @jimmypad5501
text: I love my peoples but I really need us to not mistake our lack of healing as true political commentary. Our racial traumas are real, but they are not true signs of future political behavior and making sure we are not analyzing the projections of our own pain is critically important in this moment. Electoral politics is equally about what we make happen as much as it is about analyzing what is.

Also, ngl Harris isn't an orator like Obama, but she can turn a phrase and I genuinely like it compared to the old and older combo.

author: @brandonwoods9952
text: Thank you for another great conversation. How do we factor in the fact that the Democratic presidential nominee has lost the popular vote once since 1992? That is eight election cycles. It comes down to the Electoral College (which has worked as intended - to disenfranchise the majority). It comes down to whether Harris can drive out the vote in those 4-5 states, and that's where it gets scary.

replies.author: @coss1
replies.text: True. It can easily go either way. It's going to be so close that none of us will get any sleep. I'm not a big fan of the liberals, I would much prefer Nina Turner, But I also fear Trump on an existential level.

replies.author: @user-ow6oo2uw1e
replies.text: Don't get it twisted either, the Conservatives WILL NOT stop trying to push Project 2025, even if they lose this round, they'll keep trying until it happens, one thing about the Right, they don't give up, they tried for 50 years to overturn Roe until they put enough Federalist Society goons in there to finally make it happen.

replies.author: @Itsmichelle04
replies.text:
Bill won the popular vote in 92 and 96. 
Al Gore won the popular vote against Bush by almost 600k in 2000 but lost the election. The popular vote win by Bush in was such a narrow margin, it was .7.  Obama won the popular voice twice - in 08 and 12

Hillary won the popular vote by almost 3 million votes and Joe Biden garnered more than 7 million votes than Trump.

author: @lerualnaej5917
text: I'm reminded of a comment I made to my great-aunt about Hillary. She did not like Hillary Clinton for a lot of reasons, some of which were valid, many of which were just misogyny. She kept talking about how all women in politics were xyz and she didn't like that. I remember asking her "Isn't it a problem that the only women who can make it to the national stage in politics are the ones who are xyz?" There are certain kinds of marginalized people (personality, educational and professional background, etc) who have an easier time actually getting ahead in our political system so it's not surprising that white men in positions with the most power have the most diversity of thought and background.

author: @frostedflower2032
text: Great video! This is off topic, but after the recent hurricane that tore through St.Vincent & Grenada I keep hoping that the next administration will start taking climate issues more seriously. I keep getting more worried about my family in St.Vincent and the future of all islands if things don't change soon with these historic storms. I was wondering if you've considered doing an Olay & Friends/video on how climate change will disproportionately impact black people (East coast US, Africa, & the Caribbean, etc)? I understand if this is outside of what you want to focus on. I am so glad I have been recommended your channel, your commentary has been resonating with me- thank you for your work!

author: @Lucythefallenone
text: Women are statistically more likely to hand 50% more wealth to their kids than men, she's had some progressive wins, establishment doesn't have a lot of time to sink their teeth in. She's the first first in a lot of areas and her intelligence should not be underestimated. Yes she has stances that need to improve, but I think we have more if a chance with her than any predecessor. Yes work needs to continue, but I think we have a shot for change with her and did not feel that with H Clinton. We were a couple votes shy of a 6 trillion dollar package with congress and Biden. Her momentum might bring unexpected flips in the house and senate, flips that will likely last. She will also likely get to flip or reform the Suprem Court.

author: @ChristopherSadlowski
text:
I love these chats you all have. They get my brain running in overdrive so much that I often forget to comment for the algorithm. I'll be sitting here like, "oh that's a really interesting point! It just gave me an idea I want to add to the conversation!" As I'm typing I'll hear something else really interesting and that keeps piling up until my mind can't hold everything I want to say. Once I hit that point my brain is so electrified I forget that I haven't left a comment at all. From now on I'll leave a nothing comment just to help get these videos out into other's feed.
I have thoughts and feelings about Kamala. If we thought the whitelash from Obama was bad...
I feel that if Kamala shows she can listen to young voters, take their ideas seriously, and have honest conversations it might help. I think young people want to feel involved in politics and are tired of being they're too idealistic or immature. If she can show that her mind can be changed after talking to young people and take their concerns seriously and WHY they feel the way they feel it might give her a leg up over the white supremacy that's running rampant desperately trying to maintain the status quo.

author: @lasonjahill3349
text: I wish we could stop talking about policies the potential presidential candidates are promising or running on as if they‚Äôre going to pass them unilaterally. They are not!  There‚Äôs this branch called the Legislature that controls the passing and failure of policies not the President.  If VP Harris wins the White House, you better hope she also has a Congress that will help her get those policies passed and implemented. If she doesn‚Äôt then she can‚Äôt deliver.

author: @donkeydanny2114
text:
Always look forward to having these on while meal prepping for the work weeküòÇ

As for Kamala, at least with my electoralism hat on, she might have a good chance against Trump but she is no progressive game changer. We got the aesthetics of that with Obama, but the same neoliberal policies. Her inability to distinguish herself completely from Biden so far, as well as her track record in the 2020 primaries of not being able to distinguish herself such as Bernie or Warren, does not spell good for a progressive presidency going further than Biden's (just a continuation). Definitely better than Trump though. 


With my leftist hat on, I'm very angry she  has not been able to distinguish herself clearly from Biden against Netanyahu and stand up for Gaza. Additionally, as Biden said nothing in our system will "fundamnetally change". If she sees herself as a continuation of Biden with how much she's mentioned him, she will NOT be the progressive, "cool Aunt" the media potrays her to be. Makes me even angrier considering her background (she should know the theory!) We have much work to do organizing, volunteering, and agitating.

author: @eugenebaker7800
text: If you had asked me ‚ÄúDo you think Kamala can win?‚Äù before Biden dropped out I would have said ‚ÄúNo‚Äù. But within hours after he dropped out I changed my mind. I remember telling my 8th grade Civic students back in 2016 that Kamala may became our first female POC to become President. (We did same research on how many POC have won state wide elections.)  In a country of over a 100million voters and only 10s of thousands in a few states deciding the winner, it‚Äôs hard to predict. But I truly believe she has a good chance.

author: @Autistic_Goblin
text: I can't speak for all white women, but in my opinion, I think a lot of us wish we could participate in black culture because we're terrified of being boring and basic. There really isn't much of a "white culture" beyond mayo and bland pasta salad, so the idea of a culture with a rich and vibrant history makes us envious af. I know I can't invite myself to the bbq, but it looks like so much fun!

author: @Hotshot3334
text:
In my view, this is just about the best opportunity there is to elect a woman of color to the white house. 
‚Ä¢ Trump is a known quantity and his administration was rejected last election despite voters not being enthusiastic with Biden. 
‚Ä¢ Harris will likely be seen as a continuation of the incumbency, which is very powerful. While there are many issues with this adminstration, I don't think the average voter is looking for a dramatic shift in overall policy at this time. 
‚Ä¢ Biden dropping from the race to support Harris is big news and makes for good press for the party, resulting in the enthusiasm we're seeing now.
‚Ä¢ Harris isn't that well known to the common electorate and that ambiguity means aspiration can be projected onto her more easily, unlike Clinton. 

I really think Harris has a *downhill* battle to win this election. I just hope she doesn't stumble, for all of our sakes. 
Not really looking forward to post election either.

author: @NoraMorgan
text:
Not sure it helps. I was NOT going to vote for Biden. I AM going to vote for Kamala. At the very least, I have hope she won‚Äôt be the butcher that Biden was. 
As for the perception, her leaning into her being an actual woman and the whole brat thing truly resonates with me. I think the authenticity of that is so important. It‚Äôs a great way to fight back against it being used as a negative. And I‚Äôm older. Okay dang it, I‚Äôm 51. And Hillary just is completely unlikable and it‚Äôs obvious she knows jack about regular people. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
I have hope.
And honestly, in response to your statement about white women not supporting her, I‚Äôm glad she‚Äôs a black and Asian woman and not white. If she becomes our first female president, then she‚Äôs truly broken the ceiling. I‚Äôm sure you dislike being lumped in with all other black women, being assumed to be Republican because I‚Äôm white is pretty gross.

author: @IndomitableAde
text: She might be able to win, but she won't do it with my vote. Out of NINETY-TWO counties in my red state, I don't live in one of the 3 that decide which candidate gets my state's 11 electoral votes. Plus, I don't want yet another President who will continue to turn a blind eye to the üëñO'side in Gaza, and VP Harris is that chick.

author: @literofcola
text:
Something i want Kamala, and us who advocate for abolition, to acknowledge is that 1) her history is bad, immoral, unconscionable, etc. 2) she wouldn't be in the running to be able to do good for people (nor would any other Black woman who didn't engage in nefarious acts) if she didn't. 
I could be wrong and am open to argument, but in the moment we're in, idgaf about her history. I care about what she says from now to October. 
But i really do want her to acknowledge this too, because i think people hate knowing they're being lied to. We all know the situation, and saying "I'm proud of the hard work i did, but didn't realize the extent it was hurting people," is nothing to be ashamed of. We want people to learn and improve. We also forget how strong propaganda is when people get into power. They're still in there beleiving in what America told them to. That, plus the money and power is hard to.overcome, which is why we have to keep organizing, protesting, and yeah, voting for enemies as weak as Kamala when the other choice is Trump. 
Easy for me to say, though, cause i get to vote my conscience because i live in a safe, blue state. ü§∑üèæ

She's electable if we elect her. 

And we are going to elect her! At least, I know of 159,000 other white women besides me that are also fired up to elect her! 

Harris2024üá∫üá∏

author: @clflamez6861
text: I wish her luck but she‚Äôs no Obama. Her speeches are not inspiring, her need to be down and connect with the youth is cringe, and I‚Äôm not crazy about her lying so much in the 4 years of being VP. I‚Äôm sorry but we can‚Äôt just ignore these things. Obama had a swag and aura that couldn‚Äôt be created. It wasn‚Äôt because he was a man it was because he was real with the character he led with. I get people are being misogynistic and racist towards her which is disgusting. But I do feel there are people who have valid critiques towards her. Before Joe stepped down everybody was saying Michelle Obama should run. That woman hasn‚Äôt been near the White House in years. Why? Because she is a real woman that carrys herself well. No drama, no bad past, connects with the youth. She could‚Äôve just been the wife of a president and sit in the shadow but she didn‚Äôt. She stood by Obama and was doing so much. I‚Äôm sorry but when Kamala became VP it was a run on joke that she just disappeared.

replies.author: @its_me_ke1282
replies.text: @clflamez6861¬† I hear people saying that she hasn't done anything as VP & that she just disappeared. I genuinely want to know what the VP does. The VP can't sign executive orders, can't write laws, etc. The VP usually disappears behind the President. What is the expectation for VP?

replies.author: @clflamez6861
replies.text: @its_me_ke1282 I saw Mike pence more than I saw Kamala. That is a problem. Nobody‚Äôs asking her to sign laws. Be seen and you knew she was expecting Biden to step down after the 4 years when she became vp. When democrats started saying he was running again. I saw her less. That is a problem. I‚Äôm not crazy about Biden but even he was in the public eye more than her when he was VP. She doesn‚Äôt have the I‚Äôm Old excuse. Go to colleges, go to community meetings, go to women focused organizations even if it just in blue states. Show your face.

replies.text:
I do hope you're right although I'm not quite as optimistic as you are.
But you make an excellent point about JD Vance distracting people and making the entire republican side look kinda bad right now just by being such a major weird goober. I really hope he sticks around and continues to generate horrible press for the republicans. Even Trump is pissed at him, it's beautiful.
